abstract: Ben Shpigel On Pro Football column asserts National Football League in recent years has tried to lessen brutal violence of game through rules changes, more rigorous enforcement and player fines and suspensions; effect can be seen in new passing records and higher scoring games that have increased NFL television audiences; biggest beneficiaries are quarterbacks who are now mostly injury-free and leading dynamic passing offenses.
lead_paragraph: Through rules changes, stricter enforcement, and player fines and suspensions, the N.F.L. in recent years has sought to remove the most extreme violence from an inherently violent sport.

byline.contributor: Ken Belson, Pat Borzi and Peter May contributed reporting.

snippet: Through rules changes, stricter enforcement, and player fines and suspensions, the N.F.L. in recent years has sought to remove the most extreme violence from an inherently violent sport.

headline.main: As Rules Protect Quarterbacks, N.F.L. Defenses Are on the Defensive
headline.print_headline: As Rules Protect Quarterback, Defenses Are on the Defensive
